content.webTitle: Cowgirls get to choose ... try these ranch breaks

fields.headline: Cowgirls get to choose ...
fields.bodyText: Forget pony trekking, morphing from city slickeress to cowgirl is now all the rage and ranch holidays for women are springing up like mushrooms from a cowpat. Drive cattle in the morning, brand them in the afternoon, feed the horses and mend fences, while learning to lasso in your 'spare' time. Here are some places to earn your spurs. United States Cowgirl University at Riley Ranches near Fort Worth, Texas, arranged through the National Cowgirl Museum and Hall of Fame, Fort Worth (www.cowgirl.net; 00 1 817 336 4475). Wrangler skills and rodeo. Cowgirl Bootcamp at Alisal Ranch, near Santa Barbara, California (www.alisal.com; 00 1 805 688 6411). After penning cattle, learn two-step or fly-fishing. Owned by a woman, Elkhead Ranch, Hayden, Colorado (www.ranchweb.com/elkhead; 00 1 970 276 3920). Yoga on horseback, anyone? Worldwide Become a 'jilleroo' at cowgirl school in Australia with Leconfield Jackeroo & Jilleroo School, Tamworth, New South Wales (www.leconfield.com; 00 61 2 676 94328); anything from five days to a gap year. The other Wild West - Canada. Brown Creek Ranch Vacations (www.browncreekvacations.com; 00 1 403 625 4032). Women's week called Leather & Lace (seriously). Ride with the gauchos in South America at Timote Gaucho Rides in Uruguay (www.gaucho-ride.com; 00 59 894 311 441). Pick-up from Montevideo; mix of cowgirl skills and ranch- to-ranch riding. English spoken, women-friendly, proficient riders only.
